noun.definition: A sensation of whirling and loss of balance, associated particularly with looking down from a great height, or caused by disease affecting the inner ear or the vestibular nerve; giddiness.
The state of being annoyed, frustrated, or worried.
noun.example: Jenny bit her lip in vexation

adjective.example: the proposed investment was economically viable

adjective.definition: Having or showing a strong or unreasoning desire for revenge.
adjective.example: the criticism was both vindictive and personalized

meaning: someone with master skills; expert musician;

noun.definition: A person highly skilled in music or another artistic pursuit.
A person's face, with reference to the form or proportions of the features.

adjective.definition: Having a thick, sticky consistency between solid and liquid; having a high viscosity.

meaning: to impair the quality of; corrupt morally;

verb.definition: Spoil or impair the quality or efficiency of.
verb.example: development programs have been vitiated by the rise in population

meaning: using or containing harsh; abusive censure;

adjective.example: the criticism soon turned into a vituperative attack

meaning: dissection; surgery; or painful experiments performed on a living animal for the purpose of scientific research

noun.definition: The practice of performing operations on live animals for the purpose of experimentation or scientific research (used only by people who are opposed to such work).
The prevailing fashion or style at a particular time.
noun.example: the vogue is to make realistic films

adjective.example: “citizenship” was to be the government's vogue word

verb.definition: Dance to music in such a way as to imitate the characteristic poses struck by a model on a catwalk.

adjective.definition: (of a substance) easily evaporated at normal temperatures.
Liable to change rapidly and unpredictably, especially for the worse.
adjective.example: the political situation was becoming more volatile

adjective.definition: (of a computer's memory) retaining data only as long as there is a power supply connected.

noun.definition: A mass of whirling fluid or air, especially a whirlpool or whirlwind.
noun.example: we were caught in a vortex of water

noun.definition: A document issued by a legal or government official authorizing the police or some other body to make an arrest, search premises, or carry out some other action relating to the administration of justice.
noun.example: magistrates issued a warrant for his arrest

noun.definition: Justification or authority for an action, belief, or feeling.
noun.example: there is no warrant for this assumption

noun.definition: An official certificate of appointment issued to an officer of lower rank than a commissioned officer.

verb.definition: Justify or necessitate (a certain course of action)
verb.example: that offense is serious enough to warrant a court martial

adjective.definition: Feeling or showing caution about possible dangers or problems.
adjective.example: dogs that have been mistreated often remain very wary of strangers

meaning: wallow or roll; toss about; be in turmoil

noun.definition: A large number of items in no order; a confused mass.
noun.example: there's such a welter of conflicting rules
also selected was Willie Egan at welter

adjective.definition: Playfully quaint or fanciful, especially in an appealing and amusing way.
Acting or behaving in a capricious manner.
Having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing.

meaning: one who is fanatically devoted to a cause

noun.definition: A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their religious, political, or other ideals.
